ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: how to do multi
Pretty good course I found it interesting

I started the course by learning about vectors. We then learned about vector fields and how to connect line integrals to multiple different integrals which were all based on the Fundamental Theorems of Calculus.
I learned how to evaluate derivatives and integrals in 3d space.

I feel that my ability to use practice as studying was improved by my course. In previous courses, reviewing was usually my main method of studying, but this course was very application based, so my main method of studying was practice.
Two-variable functions, 3D-space
Topics in multivariable calculus such as vectors, line integrals, etc.

I definitely learned more problem-solving skills and fundamental math knowledge of multivariable calculus like vector-valued functions, double integrals, triple integrals, and theorems like Stokes, Greens, and Divergence. I learned a little bit about how it relates to physics.
Problem solving, critical thinking, time management

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some teachers are great and some aren't so just try to find the good ones. The problem sets are way way too long though. Each one took like 8-10 hours not even because they're so hard but because they're so long.
I think it was good.
I found the lectures to not be very helpful. I mainly learned from the videos on the canvas website. It felt like the lectures just retaught what we had learned on the videos.
I personally felt the in-class lectures added little to the course and that a fully virtual course could have been just as effective.
I felt like there was a big overlap between the videos and the lectures. Watching the videos was a lot of time, but then mainly the same material was covered in class.
The course is well organized and there are lots of office hours available to attend.
Lots of content but manageable if you do the pre class lectures.

Weaknesses: It's poorly-taught. I've heard from so many peers and from my own personal experience as well how hard it is to learn in this class. The videos put on the website are the saving grace, and the Ximera modules are super helpful. The problem sets are also so different than the actual exams and take so long to do and are weighed so little to the point where it is frustrating. Even the peer tutors said they remember how difficult this class was when it doesn't have to be. The psets could be weighed a bit more because they genuinely take a really long time to do and be tailored to be more similar to the actual practice exams. I understand it is a really big blanket prerequisite for so many majors but it was just frustrating because it was a poorly taught and designed classes.

Strengths: the additional videos, the practice modules on Ximera, and the peer tutors (esp. Emily--she's incredible and better at explaining than my teacher).
Fast paced towards the end

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Sure if you need it for your major or something. It's a lot of work if you're taking it as a random class though.
Yes, this course gives you solid foundation for Math as well as fundamentals for many other subjects. It is a good foundational course useful for really anything.
Yes, its quite academically challenging and I learned a lot. It is quite a beneficial class for anyone of any major.
For a student interested in physical sciences, absolutely. For someone who is not that interested in math and just needs to fill distributional requirements, no.

I would only recommend to those who need this course to their major. I didn't find this course particularly interesting, the skills we learned are pretty much useless if not applied in some areas later.
Yes, especially if it is a prerequisite for many majors.
I wouldn't unless it's a prereq you have to take.
Yes, it gives a solid foundation.

If you can take this class with Sung Jin Park, do it with him. Incredible during office hours, which he scheduled right after class, and facilitated a solid conceptual understanding of the material that made common pitfalls very avoidable.
